an3.114:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the appearance of three individuals is rare in the world.

an3.114:1.3.pli: Tathāgatassa, bhikkhave, arahato sammāsambuddhassa pātubhāvo dullabho lokasmiṃ, tathāgatappaveditassa dhammavinayassa desetā puggalo dullabho lokasmiṃ, kataññū katavedī puggalo dullabho lokasmiṃ.
an3.114:1.3.eng: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. A teacher of the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One. An individual who is grateful and thankful.

an3.114:1.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ pātubhāvo dullabho lokasmin”ti.
an3.114:1.4.eng: The appearance of these three individuals is rare in the world.”

an3.115:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three individuals are found in the world.

an3.115:1.3.eng: Someone easy to measure, someone hard to measure, and someone who is immeasurable.

an3.115:1.4.eng: And who is the individual easy to measure?

an3.115:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo uddhato hoti unnaḷo capalo mukharo vikiṇṇavāco muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
an3.115:1.5.eng: It’s an individual who is restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.

an3.115:1.6.eng: This is called ‘an individual easy to measure’.

an3.115:2.1.eng: And who is the individual hard to measure?

an3.115:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo anuddhato hoti anunnaḷo acapalo amukharo avikiṇṇavāco upaṭṭhitassati sampajāno samāhito ekaggacitto saṃvutindriyo.
an3.115:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who is not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, or loose-tongued. They have established mindfulness, situational awareness and immersion, with unified mind and restrained faculties.

an3.115:2.3.eng: This is called ‘an individual hard to measure’.

an3.115:3.1.eng: And who is the immeasurable individual?

an3.115:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo.
an3.115:3.2.eng: It’s a mendicant who is perfected, and has ended defilements.

an3.115:3.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an3.115:3.4.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.”

an3.116:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three individuals are found in the world.

an3.116:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.116:1.3.eng: First, an individual, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an3.116:1.4.pli: So tadassādeti taṃ nikāmeti tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati, tatra ṭhito tadadhimutto tabbahulavihārī aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno ākāsānañcāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an3.116:1.4.eng: They enjoy it and like it and find it rewarding. If they’re set on that, committed to it, and meditate on it often without losing it, when they die they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of infinite space.

an3.116:1.5.pli: Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagānaṃ, bhikkhave, devānaṃ vīsati kappasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.116:1.5.eng: The lifespan of the gods of infinite space is twenty thousand eons.

an3.116:1.6.pli: Tattha puthujjano yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā nirayampi gacchati tiracchānayonimpi gacchati pettivisayampi gacchati.
an3.116:1.6.eng: An ordinary person stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they go to hell or the animal realm or the ghost realm.

an3.116:1.7.pli: Bhagavato pana sāvako tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā tasmiṃyeva bhave parinibbāyati.
an3.116:1.7.eng: But a disciple of the Buddha stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they’re extinguished in that very life.

an3.116:1.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso ayaṃ adhippayāso idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanena, yadidaṃ gatiyā upapattiyā.
an3.116:1.8.eng: This is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an unlearned ordinary person as regards their place of rebirth.

an3.116:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.116:2.1.eng: Furthermore, an individual, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an3.116:2.2.pli: So tadassādeti taṃ nikāmeti tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati, tatra ṭhito tadadhimutto tabbahulavihārī aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno viññāṇañcāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an3.116:2.2.eng: They enjoy it and like it and find it rewarding. If they’re set on that, committed to it, and meditate on it often without losing it, when they die they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an3.116:2.3.pli: Viññāṇañcāyatanūpagānaṃ, bhikkhave, devānaṃ cattārīsaṃ kappasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.116:2.3.eng: The lifespan of the gods of infinite consciousness is forty thousand eons.

an3.116:2.4.pli: Tattha puthujjano yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā nirayampi gacchati tiracchānayonimpi gacchati pettivisayampi gacchati.
an3.116:2.4.eng: An ordinary person stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they go to hell or the animal realm or the ghost realm.

an3.116:2.5.pli: Bhagavato pana sāvako tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā tasmiṃyeva bhave parinibbāyati.
an3.116:2.5.eng: But a disciple of the Buddha stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they’re extinguished in that very life.

an3.116:2.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso ayaṃ adhippayāso idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanena, yadidaṃ gatiyā upapattiyā.
an3.116:2.6.eng: This is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an unlearned ordinary person as regards their place of rebirth.

an3.116:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.116:3.1.eng: Furthermore, an individual, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an3.116:3.2.pli: So tadassādeti taṃ nikāmeti tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati, tatra ṭhito tadadhimutto tabbahulavihārī aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno ākiñcaññāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an3.116:3.2.eng: They enjoy it and like it and find it rewarding. If they’re set on that, committed to it, and meditate on it often without losing it, when they die they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of nothingness.

an3.116:3.3.pli: Ākiñcaññāyatanūpagānaṃ, bhikkhave, devānaṃ saṭṭhi kappasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.116:3.3.eng: The lifespan of the gods of nothingness is sixty thousand eons.

an3.116:3.4.pli: Tattha puthujjano yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā nirayampi gacchati tiracchānayonimpi gacchati pettivisayampi gacchati.
an3.116:3.4.eng: An ordinary person stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they go to hell or the animal realm or the ghost realm.

an3.116:3.5.pli: Bhagavato pana sāvako tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yāvatakaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ khepetvā tasmiṃyeva bhave parinibbāyati.
an3.116:3.5.eng: But a disciple of the Buddha stays there until the lifespan of those gods is spent, then they’re extinguished in that very life.

an3.116:3.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso, ayaṃ adhippayāso idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanena, yadidaṃ gatiyā upapattiyā.
an3.116:3.6.eng: This is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an unlearned ordinary person as regards their place of rebirth.

an3.116:3.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an3.116:3.7.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.”

an3.117:1.3.eng: Failure in ethics, mind, and view.

an3.117:1.4.eng: And what is failure in ethics?

an3.117:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti, musāvādī hoti, pisuṇavāco hoti, pharusavāco hoti, samphappalāpī hoti.
an3.117:1.5.eng: It’s when someone kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, and uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.117:2.1.eng: And what is failure in mind?

an3.117:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti byāpannacitto.
an3.117:2.2.eng: It’s when someone is covetous and malicious.

an3.117:3.1.eng: And what is failure in view?

an3.117:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti viparītadassano:
an3.117:3.2.eng: It’s when someone has wrong view, a distorted perspective, such as:

an3.117:3.3.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.117:3.3.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.117:3.5.pli: Sīlavipattihetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti;
an3.117:3.5.eng: Some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell because of failure in ethics,

an3.117:3.6.pli: cittavipattihetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti;

an3.117:3.7.pli: diṭṭhivipattihetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.

an3.117:4.3.eng: Accomplishment in ethics, mind, and view.

an3.117:5.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in ethics?

an3.117:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.117:5.2.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, or use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.117:5.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in ethics.

an3.117:6.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in mind?

an3.117:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti abyāpannacitto.
an3.117:6.2.eng: It’s when someone is content and kind-hearted.

an3.117:6.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in mind.

an3.117:7.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in view?

an3.117:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti aviparītadassano:
an3.117:7.2.eng: It’s when someone has right view, an undistorted perspective, such as:

an3.117:7.3.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ, atthi hutaṃ, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, atthi ayaṃ loko, atthi paro loko, atthi mātā, atthi pitā, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.117:7.3.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.117:7.4.eng: This is called accomplishment in view.

an3.117:7.5.pli: Sīlasampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti;
an3.117:7.5.eng: Some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm because of accomplishment in ethics,

an3.117:7.6.pli: cittasampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti;

an3.117:7.7.pli: diṭṭhisampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.

an3.118:1.3.eng: Failure in ethics, mind, and view.

an3.118:2.1.eng: And what is failure in ethics?

an3.118:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti …pe… samphappalāpī hoti.
an3.118:2.2.eng: It’s when someone kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, and uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.118:3.1.eng: And what is failure in mind?

an3.118:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti byāpannacitto.
an3.118:3.2.eng: It’s when someone is covetous and malicious.

an3.118:4.1.eng: And what is failure in view?

an3.118:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti viparītadassano:
an3.118:4.2.eng: It’s when someone has wrong view, a distorted perspective, such as:

an3.118:4.3.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.118:4.3.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.118:4.5.pli: Sīlavipattihetu vā, bhikkhave …pe… diṭṭhivipattihetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
an3.118:4.5.eng: Some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell because of failure in ethics, mind, or view.

an3.118:4.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, apaṇṇako maṇi uddhaṃ khitto yena yeneva patiṭṭhāti suppatiṭṭhitaṃyeva patiṭṭhāti;
an3.118:4.6.eng: It’s like throwing unfailing dice: they always fall the right side up.

an3.118:4.7.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sīlavipattihetu vā sattā …pe… upapajjanti.
an3.118:4.7.eng: In the same way, some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell because of failure in ethics, mind, or view.

an3.118:5.3.eng: Accomplishment in ethics, mind, and view.

an3.118:6.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in ethics?

an3.118:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe…
an3.118:6.2.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, or use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.118:6.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in ethics.

an3.118:7.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in mind?

an3.118:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti abyāpannacitto.
an3.118:7.2.eng: It’s when someone is content and kind-hearted.

an3.118:7.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in mind.

an3.118:8.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in view?

an3.118:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti aviparītadassano:
an3.118:8.2.eng: It’s when someone has right view, an undistorted perspective, such as:

an3.118:8.3.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.118:8.3.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.118:8.4.eng: This is called accomplishment in view.

an3.118:8.5.pli: Sīlasampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti. Cittasampadāhetu vā …pe… diṭṭhisampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
an3.118:8.5.eng: Some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm because of accomplishment in ethics, mind, or view.

an3.118:8.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, apaṇṇako maṇi uddhaṃ khitto yena yeneva patiṭṭhāti suppatiṭṭhitaṃyeva patiṭṭhāti;
an3.118:8.6.eng: It’s like throwing unfailing dice: they always fall the right side up.

an3.118:8.7.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sīlasampadāhetu vā sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti, cittasampadāhetu vā sattā …pe… diṭṭhisampadāhetu vā sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
an3.118:8.7.eng: In the same way, some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm because of accomplishment in ethics, mind, or view.

an3.119:1.3.eng: Failure in action, livelihood, and view.

an3.119:1.4.eng: And what is failure in action?

an3.119:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti …pe… samphappalāpī hoti.
an3.119:1.5.eng: It’s when someone kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, and uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.119:2.1.eng: And what is failure in livelihood?

an3.119:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchāājīvo hoti, micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti.
an3.119:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has wrong livelihood and earns a living by wrong livelihood.

an3.119:3.1.eng: And what is failure in view?

an3.119:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti viparītadassano:
an3.119:3.2.eng: It’s when someone has wrong view, a distorted perspective, such as:

an3.119:3.3.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.119:3.3.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.119:4.3.eng: Accomplishment in action, livelihood, and view.

an3.119:4.4.eng: And what is accomplishment in action?

an3.119:4.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.119:4.5.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, or use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.119:5.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in livelihood?

an3.119:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammāājīvo hoti, sammāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti.
an3.119:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has right livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.

an3.119:6.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in view?

an3.119:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti aviparītadassano:
an3.119:6.2.eng: It’s when someone has right view, an undistorted perspective, such as:

an3.119:6.3.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
an3.119:6.3.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

an3.12:1.1.pli: “Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyāni bhavanti.
an3.12:1.1.eng: “An anointed aristocratic king should commemorate three places as long as he lives.

an3.12:1.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, padese rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto jāto hoti.

an3.12:1.4.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ padese rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto hoti.
an3.12:2.1.eng: The place he was anointed as king.

an3.12:2.2.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ padese rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an3.12:3.1.eng: The place where he won victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an3.12:3.2.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:3.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyāni bhavanti.
an3.12:3.3.eng: These are the three places an anointed king should commemorate as long as he lives.

an3.12:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīṇimāni bhikkhussa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyāni bhavanti.
an3.12:4.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant should commemorate three places as long as they live.

an3.12:4.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, padese bhikkhu kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti.
an3.12:4.3.eng: The place where the mendicant shaved off their hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an3.12:4.4.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ bhikkhussa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ padese bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an3.12:5.1.eng: The place where the mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an3.12:5.2.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ bhikkhussa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ padese bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.12:6.1.eng: The place where the mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.12:6.2.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ bhikkhussa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hoti.

an3.12:6.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi bhikkhussa yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyāni bhavantī”ti.
an3.12:6.3.eng: These are the three places a mendicant should commemorate as long as they live.”

an3.120:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three kinds of purity.

an3.120:1.3.eng: Purity of body, speech, and mind.

an3.120:1.4.eng: And what is purity of body?

an3.120:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.120:1.5.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct.

an3.120:2.1.eng: And what is purity of speech?

an3.120:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.120:2.2.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.120:3.1.eng: And what is purity of mind?

an3.120:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti abyāpannacitto sammādiṭṭhiko.
an3.120:3.2.eng: It’s when someone is content, kind-hearted, and has right view.

an3.120:3.4.eng: These are the three kinds of purity.”

an3.121:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three kinds of purity.

an3.121:1.3.eng: Purity of body, speech, and mind.

an3.121:1.4.eng: And what is purity of body?

an3.121:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, abrahmacariyā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.121:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or have sex.

an3.121:2.1.eng: And what is purity of speech?

an3.121:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.121:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.121:3.1.eng: And what is purity of mind?

an3.121:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ kāmacchandaṃ: ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ kāmacchandaṃ: ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca uppannassa kāmacchandassa pahānaṃ hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca pahīnassa kāmacchandassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti;
an3.121:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has sensual desire in them understands ‘I have sensual desire in me.’ When they don’t have sensual desire in them, they understand ‘I don’t have sensual desire in me.’ They understand how sensual desire arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

an3.121:3.3.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ byāpādaṃ: ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ byāpādo’ti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ byāpādaṃ: ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ byāpādo’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa byāpādassa uppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca uppannassa byāpādassa pahānaṃ hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca pahīnassa byāpādassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti;
an3.121:3.3.eng: When they have ill will in them they understand ‘I have ill will in me’; and when they don’t have ill will in them they understand ‘I don’t have ill will in me’. They understand how ill will arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

an3.121:3.4.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhaṃ: ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhaṃ: ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa thinamiddhassa uppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca uppannassa thinamiddhassa pahānaṃ hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca pahīnassa thinamiddhassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti;
an3.121:3.4.eng: When they have dullness and drowsiness in them they understand ‘I have dullness and drowsiness in me’; and when they don’t have dullness and drowsiness in them they understand ‘I don’t have dullness and drowsiness in me’. They understand how dullness and drowsiness arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

an3.121:3.5.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ: ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ: ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca uppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānaṃ hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca pahīnassa uddhaccakukkuccassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti;
an3.121:3.5.eng: When they have restlessness and remorse in them they understand ‘I have restlessness and remorse in me’; and when they don’t have restlessness and remorse in them they understand ‘I don’t have restlessness and remorse in me’. They understand how restlessness and remorse arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

an3.121:3.6.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vicikicchaṃ: ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti; asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ vicikicchaṃ: ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti; yathā ca anuppannāya vicikicchāya uppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca uppannāya vicikicchāya pahānaṃ hoti, tañca pajānāti; yathā ca pahīnāya vicikicchāya āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca pajānāti.
an3.121:3.6.eng: When they have doubt in them they understand ‘I have doubt in me’; and when they don’t have doubt in them they understand ‘I don’t have doubt in me’. They understand how doubt arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

an3.121:3.8.eng: These are the three kinds of purity.

an3.121:4.1.eng: Purity of body, purity of speech,

an3.121:4.3.eng: A pure one, blessed with purity,

an3.121:4.4.eng: has washed off all bad things, they say.”
